title: Set Up Equation For Problem
text: From the picture, we can see the diagonal and the two sides of the square form a right triangle, we can employ pythagorean theorem. $$a^2+b^2=c^2$$ where a and $$b$$ are legs of triangles and c is the hypotenuse. Let s be the length of the side of square. We can set up the equation as $$s^2+s^2=\left(s+3\right)^2$$.

Solve For Unknown Using Quadratic Formula
text: $$s^2+s^2=\left(s+3\right)^2$$ can be simplified as $$9w^2-10w-25=0$$. Solve for $$x$$ using the quadratic formula and round $$x$$ to the nearest hundredth. If there is more than one solution for $$x$$, please enter your answer as (a,b) where $$a<b$$.

title: Solve For Unknown Using Quadratic Formula
text: Since the length of the side of a sqaure has to be positive, we can omit the negative answer. Therefore the $$s=7.24$$. The the diagonal of rectangle is $$s+3$$ which is $$7.24+3=10.24$$. We can round it to nearest tenth which gives $$10.2$$.
